Well I don’t like him. Why does he write on the mountain? It’s not his!  60. EXT. —- PUEBLA FREEWAY - CERRO LA CALDERA - DAY The Valiant plows on eastward. In the background the Cerr Caldera, longing to be a mountain, delineates the boundar the city as it melts into the slums. The west slope of the hill has been desecrated by three immense white letters extending almost all along and acro its dry surface - LEA. Like a curse. EXT. - ZAVALETA HACIENDA —- DAY A great adobe wall surrounds an immense property in the middle of fields. The Valiant crosses an enormous gate in EXT. —- ENTRANCE - ZAVALETA HACIENDA - DAY A road crosses the enormous walled esplanade. In the background, the beautiful wall of the hacienda, a monumen Profirian estates. The Valiant reaches the Big House. A dozen cars are parke a row to one side of the road. All large luxury cars of t year: LTDs, Impalas and Country Squires. The ‘64 Valiant parks between an LTD and a Country Squire making its mileage and its peeling paint very obvious. Th get out of the car. Sefiora Sofia opens the trunk and Cleo starts to pull out luggage, her belly barely noticeable. A group of people comes out of the Big House to greet the three adults, some kids and several servants. CLAUDIA DE BARCENA, 38, SAMANTHA LARSSON, also 38, a high-class Mexi with died blond hair and MOLLY EDWARDS, an affable blond Welsh woman, 37, all throw their arms up in the air -
Comadre!
BENITA, 55 years old, the Hacienda housekeeper, guides Cl down a long corridor. Both carry several bags some in the hands others hanging from their shoulders.
You sure you can carry that?  61.
Yes, I’m with child, not sick. What? You tired already? Cleo hurries forward. Benita does the same, following her
As if!

I haven't seen you for six months and you got old on me. The two women race hurriedly, buried under bags like ants carrying several times their own weight. Benita catches up with Cleo, who hurries on and overtakes her. But Benita stops -
Where you going? Cleo stops. Benita is standing next to a door -

You've gone too far. What? Since you're pregnant you forget everything? Cleo smiles and walks back. INT. - CHILDREN’S ROOM - HACIENDA - DAY A hall full of bunk beds, rudimentary but functional. The are several bags next to the beds and there are toys on t of some already. Lined up along all the walls there are stuffed dog heads. Cleo leaves the luggage next to a bunk bed and looks at t heads.
Sefior José had the room redecorated. They’re the Hacienda dogs. Look... They were all in storage. They look at a German Shepherd’s head with glass eyes.  62.
Look, that there is Pirata. He lived here in 1911. A small plaque confirms this. It also indicates his name Pirata. Cleo looks on, impressed.
Pirata...
And do you remember Canela?
Yeah, where’s she at?
Look at her. Cleo looks at an Irish Setter’s head.
Yikes!
She died during the summer. Cleo looks at Canela, horrified.

They say she must have eaten a poisoned rat. But I think it was the villagers who are bothering Don José again about the land... Canela looks at them with her glass eyes. EXT —- SMALL CLEARING IN THE WOODS - HACIENDA - DAY The winter light filters through the trees and reflects o the great puddle stretching between the clearing and the woods. Children run between the trees throwing firecrackers, two dogs follow them, jumping in the puddle. Adults are practicing shooting bottles lined up on tree stumps with caliber pistols at the other end of the clearing.  63. With the exception of nannies and servants looking after younger children, everyone is white and, except for Sefio Sofia and her children, they’re dressed in imported cloth The sound of shots fuses with the firecrackers. Tofio plays “tochito” flag-football with PEPE DE LA BARCE 13, EDUARDO LARSSON, a 12 year-old redhead, and RICKY EDWARDS, 11. Cleo looks after Pepe and keeps LUPE, 30, company as well YOLA, 22, who look after JORGE DE LA BARCENA, 7, who suff from intellectual disability, and partial paralysis in a and arm, and his brother MEMO, 5, who has autism spectre disorder. They’re sitting on a tablecloth, playing with Matchbox cars. A little further back, GLORIA, 34, who works as a nanny w the Edwards’, sits on another tablecloth with a toy china set, probably more expensive than a real one, and looks a Sofi who is playing with JULY EDWARDS, 7, VERO MATOS, 8, ANDREA, a girl whose blond hair is almost white, also 8. GERARDO LARSSON, 10, a flamboyant chubby redhead plays wi them too. Paco, along with RODRI DE LA BARCENA, 10, ALEX MATOS, 10 ANDY EDWARDS, 8, appear from behind the trees and throw firecrackers at the girls. They scream. Some even cry.
I saw you, Paco! Get out of here! The boys run off, laughing and splashing across the puddl

Rodri! Don’t run in the water! You're soaking wet! Dr. ALEJANDRO MATOS, 40, with a goatee, shoots while smok his pipe. Next to him, RICARDO EDWARDS, friendly, 39, OVE LARSSON, towering redheaded shy Norwegian, 41, and LESLIE MATOS, a blond American, 38 also shoot while DR. JOSE DE LA BARCEN 41, waits his turn and CELSO, the hacienda foreman, 35, reloads the guns.
Celso, do you still have bullets or should I send Lupe to get the ones in the chest?
A few yards away, Sofia, Claudia, Molly and Samantha sit folding chairs, chatting. Sefiora Sofia sees the boys running through the trees. Sh gets up and yells -
Don’t run over there, you could get shot! Molly seconds her, with her thick accent -

Boys! Vayase! Andy, get back! FLOR, 17, a servant from the Hacienda, stands at a table a cooler, pouring the adults drinks, LOLA, 12 going on 19, made up, dressed in a tiny mini-ski and platform shoes, takes advantage of the adults’ distraction to pour whisky into her Coca-Cola. Next to he CLAU DE LA BARCENA, 11, seems amused, but her curiosity d not yet supersede her obedience. ON THE CHILDREN'S TABLECLOTH -— The interaction with Jorge and Memo is difficult so Pepe bored and watches the shooting party. He gets up and walk over there.

Wait, Pepe. Where are you going? Pepe just points and keeps walking. Cleo follows him and reach the - SHOOTING PARTY -— Where Dr. Alejandro Matos has fired his eight rounds and to Celso to recharge his gun. He calls to the women on th folding chairs -
What? Don’t ladies shoot? The women decline with their hands -
Leslie is our representative!  65.
Leslie doesn’t count, she’s a gringa. The women laugh. Claudia gets up -
Coming!

(In English) Yes, Claudia. You show them, girl! Celso gives Alejandro the reloaded gun while Leslie arriv with hers. Celso takes it and quickly reloads it. Pepe pi up the empty cartridges off the ground. Cleo helps him. Celso gives Alejandro a loaded gun, who gives it to Claud
(in English) Leslie, could you help Claudia?
Come. Point the gun to the floor when you’re not using it. Cokes in hand, Clau and Lola mingle with the adults. They come upon Leslie -
(In English) C’mon, Lola. You really have to wear a miniskirt and platform shoes? We’re in the woods. Lola keeps walking and pays no attention to her mother.
Forget her. You look great, Lola. Lola and Clau reach the shooting party and its male acceptance.
Let’s see Lola, you want to shoot?
Sure. Lola walks up to José who gives her the gun while he hugs from the back, to “help” her shoot.  66.
Don’t close your eyes when you shoot... Cleo looks at Alejandro walking over to the drink table tended by Flor.
Can you pour me a whisky with two ice cubes? Flor fixes his drink.
Everyone celebrates Claudia’s nailing two bottles. She sh four more shots in a row and pops off four more bottles. Everyone celebrates -—

Be careful Pepe, your wife is like a guerrilla fighter! Everyone laughs. Flor hands Alejandro his whisky and, taking advantage of confusion, he spanks her. Flor runs away, terrified. More bottles explode.

Dozens of floor lamps and table lamps light an immense na with an enormous chimney guzzling up thick logs facing a broad living room with huge leather sofas decorated with furs. Adults converse, some sitting on the couches, others standing, all are drinking and some are smoking. Pepe is Sofi’s lap, and Gerardo is next to his mother. Yvonne Elliman’s voice rings through the air, singing “I Don’t Know How to Love You.” The girls play cards in a lo table in front of the French window that opens to a terra Outside, the boys throw firecrackers and rockets. Other boys play “Trominos” on the floor and in a smaller living room, Lola, drink in hand, gossips with Clau. Cleo is with Yola, who looks after Memo, who is obsessive turning a plate on the floor, and after Jorge, who plays a little car.  67.

Pepe, July Edwards and Andrew Larsson come in from the terrace howling and laughing, chased after by a strange monster. It’s a scarecrow with a straw body and long furs wooden mask covering its face. Something like a pagan spirit, rum and coke in hand, now chasing after the younger children, who flee happily. Cleo sees Flor walk in with a tray carrying too many milk and milkshakes. She hurries to help her - The milk glasses dance perilously on the platter while Fl loses her balance, but Cleo rushes just in the nick of ti Together they walk over to the table and serve beverages the girls. The scratch of a needle on a record as the metals of an orchestra blast a mambo rhythm: the tune changes to Perez Prado’s “Coraz6n de Melén.” Samantha jumps up with a cry and starts to dance -
Come on, comadre! Sofia and Molly get up and dance with her. Ricardo Edward his Ricky Ricardo impersonation, walks by yelling -

Co-ra-z6n de melén, de meldén meldn! Corazon! He joins in the dancing. Alejandro follows and dances wit Sofia. Lola and Clau also join, Gerardo dances with his mother. Ove with July. Benita comes into the living room and looks around. Molly trying to get Vero and Andrea to go to bed, but they don’ want to. Cleo and Flor look on, amused, sucked in by the Mambo. Cl sees - Pepe, joining the dance and going up to his mother, who p no attention since she’s too busy dancing with Alejandro. Benita walks up to Cleo.
Come her for a sec.  68.
Cleo looks at her, confused -
Just come over for a sec. Cleo looks around -
But... what if?
What? Is a kid going to cry because he lost at marbles or his brother stepped on him? Cleo looks at her, amused, and follows her. They cross th room to the entrance.
Co-ra-z6n de me-lén, de me-lén, me- 16n, co-ra-zén!
Benita guides Cleo, who follows amused and curious down t corridor lit with candles. The leave the MAMBO behind and down -

The stone staircase leads down to an internal patio that doubles as storage. A couple of men chat, lit by the light from a kitchen win Inside there’s a racket around an accordion exhaling a ranchera-style polka. Three dogs meander about the patio, waiting for a New Yea gift. Benita and Cleo walk into -
A hall with a vaulted ceiling lit by bare light bulbs hos an enormous ancient kitchen with wood burning stoves, a g table, a Mabe stove and two 1961 refrigerators.  69.

The Hacienda WORKERS celebrate New Year’s. Benita guides to the table. Women are serving plates of food from large clay pots. A year-old man plays the accordion and some spontaneous guy improvises a quebradita dance with Gloria, who is clearly drunk. She sees Cleo -
What? They finally let you out? Cleo laughs. At the table, everyone drinks, some eat, som are dressed for the occasion, many are not. A 1959 televi set transmits Channel 2’s New Year’s special.
What’1l you have?
Nothing, thank you.
What? You’re not going to toast the New Year with us? What, you only speak English now?
It’s just that... the baby...
A drink on New Year’s will do it good. Celebrate while you can. See that guy with the hat? Cleo sees a man with a hat talking somberly with two othe men -
They killed his son in August. The villagers did. Because of a land dispute. Cleo looks at him, moved.
You got life?
Sure...
I mean liquor.  70.
Benita pours her a shot of moonshine.
I'd rather just have a little pulque.
That's the spirit! She pours pulque into a jar and hands it to Cleo. The two toast.
Here’s to a beautiful 1971 and to your baby’s health!

Cheers! Benita takes the jar to her lips and Cleo draws her pulqu close to hers when Gloria trips dancing her quebradita an bumps into Cleo. Before even touching her lips, the pulque jar falls to th ground and shatters into a million pieces.
Sorry, manita!

No sweat. You dance, we got plenty more where that came from! She pours pulque into a new jar. Gloria keeps dancing. Cl holds the other pulque but looks worriedly down at the shattered jar on the floor. INT. —- INTERNAL PATIO - STAIRS - HACIENDA - NIGHT Cleo exits the kitchen. She’s a little tipsy. The patio i empty except for the dogs who follow her until she reache the stairs that lead up to - EXT. — CORRIDOR - HACIENDA - NIGHT Cleo walks down the candle-lit corridor and back into the living room where “Mummy Blues” is playing on the stereo. sees a silhouette resting on the balustrade: it’s Sefiora Sofia.  71.
Alejandro Matos comes out of the parlour and comes close Sofia, hugging her from behind. Sofia reacts, turning aro in surprise.
What are you doing? Alejandro tries to kiss her, but she rejects him.
Come, now... You know you want to... Sofia struggles to free herself.
No, Alex! Leave me alone! You’re drunk! She pushes him. Alejandro holds his hands up, resentful a resigned -

Fine. Fine! I just wanted to comfort you, but... He begins to walk back into the parlour. DR. ALEJANDRO MATOS (CONT’D) It’s not even like you’re that hot, comadre... Sefiora Sofia leans into the balustrade, confused and agitated. She looks in Cleo’s direction, but Cleo hides behind a column. Sefiora Sofia walks back into the parlour, Cleo waits for to leave before coming out of her hiding spot. She leans the balustrade and looks out at the night. When her eyes get used to the darkness, she can see the darker silhouettes of the trees in front of a sky that se to be lit from within. The cricket song melts into “Mummy Blues”, ending on a scratch, and the accordion which seems to be playing a mazurca. The wind blows softly. Through the darkness in the woods, a pale light appears, almost blending into the night. Cleo watches in fascinati  72.

The Shocking Blue’s “Venus” starts to play. The dogs star barking. The shining starts to spread out in a warm, attractive pulsing, like a will o’ the wisp or an apparition. Cleo watches, hypnotized. But what started off as a soft begins to rip through the night in an intense gleam that dances in the trees. The barks become more insistent. Someone screams -

Fire! Fire! In the woods! A racket. More screaming. More barking. In the garden, Celso runs, carrying a bucket. Other worke follow after him, carrying buckets and pots overflowing w water. They run towards the woods in flames. EXT -— SMALL CLEARING IN THE WOODS - HACIENDA - NIGHT The giant puddle reflects the flames dancing over the roc on the ground. The fire licks the trees and spreads into branches. The flames push forward, devouring the clearing grass, th very same place where just this afternoon they were all shooting. Celso runs to the fire and empties out his bucket. The workers do the same. They come back for more water and cr paths with yet other workers carrying various containers. Dr. José arrives carrying two buckets, followed by Ricard Edwards, with one. Further behind, Dr. Alejandro Matos an Leslie carry a heavy washbasin. Gloria, Flor, Yola and Cleo all bring their containers. E the kids. Everyone runs, comes, goes... the dogs keep the distance. A human chain starts to form: buckets pass from hand to h everyone trying to put out the fire. The pagan monster with his drink in hand arrives. He look his watch -  73.
(In English) 23...22...21...20...19...18...17... The monster takes off his mask, revealing a sweaty and dr Ove -
The human chain begins to work efficiently. Pepe even put out a few blades of glass with his little cup.
eT Gee See dbe ee Sec e2ecelece
But no one pays attention. Everyone is working, trying to control the fire.
Happy New year! Ove starts singing in Norwegian. It’s an emotional Nyttar song.
Pkfmsll apdkfn alosnnm... The children go to the puddle and fill up their little containers. The dogs follow them, splashing. The reflecti is disarticulated in waves that bump into each other.
Pkfmsll apdkfn alosnnm... Ove sings with conviction. His eyes fill with tears. Friday, January lst, 1971.
Dew makes the woods shine, though they’re still dark and smoking. The first rays of the new year sun filter throug the trees. Four folding chairs rest the middle of the clearing, char  74.

The Iztaccihuatl sleeps, immense, behind the hills and du crops. The afternoon light filters through rain-leaden clouds. A group of children run and explore. Tofio, Pepe de la Barcena, Ricky, Paco, Rodri, Alex and Eduardo lead the front throwing each other football passe Paco, Rodri, and Alex chase after chameleons in the furro Lola and Clau walk next to them. Vero, Sofi, Gerardo, And and July are further back. Pepe and Andy walk with Yola. Cleo walks with Benita. The dogs run everywhere. Alex cha after a chameleon, Rodri and Paco follow.
Don’t run too far. We’ll just reach to the outskirts and come back! Paco stops-—
What skirts?
The hillside. Paco laughs.
You mean the hill has skirts?
The outskirts... well, the slopes then!
Alex, the hill has a skirt! Alex stops.
If we lean over we’ll be able to see its panties. Paco pretends to lean and Alex does the same. Lola and Cl catch up to them -
What are you guys doing?  75.
Looking up the hill’s skirts to see its panties.
Hills don’t have underwear. Paco leans under her and lifts up her miniskirt.
And neither do you! Lola screams and pats down her skirt -—
Asshole!
Ooooooh! Alex lifts up Clau’s dress. She screams.

Alex! Paco! Leave the girls alone! The boys run, amused. Cleo and Benita stop. A gust of wind conjures dust devils low thunder rumbles and rain falls in the distance. Cleo looks at the landscape dreamily. Her hands rest on h belly.
It’s like my village. Without the mountain, of course, but it looks just like this... She enjoys the moment while she rubs her belly. She close her eyes -
This is how it sounds... The church bells ringing and the bleating of goats get lo in the distance.
Just like this... She breathes. Breathes deep. She smiles -  76.
This is how it smells... Cleo is somewhere else. Friday, January 29, 1971.

The Valiant is parked in front of the house, next to the Galaxie 500. The Valiant overflows with the children. One more comes o Tofio’s friend, BETO PARDO, 12, with glasses and good-boy looks. He’s come for lunch. Paco shows off the black Galaxie, its scrapes and bent moldings recently repaired -—
Look, they fixed it all up. Just like new, right? Beto barely looks at it. He keeps going and goes into the house after Tofo.
Cleo’s belly is starting to show. She cuts Pepe’s meat. Sefiora Teresa eats in silence. The children talk while t eat -
The Cowboys won only because Baltimore was overconfident.
What are you talking about? We scored three touchdowns in the second half. One after the other! Sefiora Sofia comes down the stairs and into the breakfas room.  77.
I’m telling you. Baltimore was overconfident. How can you root for the Cowboys?
I like the Cowboy’s cheerleaders. In my school...
Who cares about cheerleaders? Sefiora Sofia comes into the breakfast room. Her face is drawn. Sefiora Teresa looks at her, worried.
Ma? Can Beto and I go to the movies? Sefiora Sofia is absent -
What are you going to see?
The Red Tent, at The Americas theater.
I want to go too!
No, just Beto and me.
How come?
Get yourself your own friends!
I want to go to the movies too!
I said no! It’s just me and Beto. Sefiora Sofia explodes -
Either everyone goes or no one goes!  78.
They can go to a different movie!
I want to go to Las Americas!
You don’t even know what The Red Tent is!
I said, either everyone goes or no one goes! The telephone rings, Sefiora Sofia gets up and walks to t hall to answer -
It’s not fair! Sefiora Sofia comes back -
If you don’t like it you can go live somewhere else! She walks over to pick up the phone, leaving Tofio furiou Paco smiles impertinently.
Is it a cartoon? Sefiora Sofia answers -

Hello? Oh, yes, hold on a minute... She calls to the breakfast room - SENORA SOF{A (CONT’D) Cleo! I’m going to get this upstairs, would you mind hanging up here! She goes upstairs. Cleo walks to the phone and she hears Sefiora Sofia calling -  79.
There...! Cleo is about to hang up the phone when she overhears...
How are you feeling, comadre? Cleo hangs up.
Everyone’s ready to go to the movies. Sefiora Teresa is g too, because she worries and because she loves going to t movies. She calls up to the children -
We're late! You coming down or what? Paco and Sofi are already by her side.
Let them stay. Let’s go...
We're leaving! Sefiora Teresa goes out to the Patio with Cleo, Paco, Sof Pepe.
The group reaches the street entrance and Sefiora Teresa the door. Borras takes advantage of the situation to run despite Cleo and Paco’s attempts to stop him. Paco runs out.
He chases the dog down and drags him back into the house where the group is waiting outside the door. Paco leaves the dog inside and is about to close the door when Toho and Beto come out.
What are you waiting for?  80.
The two hurry up to the corner heading towards Insurgente Everyone follows them.
Tofo and Beto are at the front. Cleo and Sefiora Teresa l after Sofi and Pepe who is talking to Paco about planes.
..-Braniff planes may be different colors but they’re all 727s... They're on Tepic street, near Insurgentes when Tofio and take off in a well planned strategy.
See you at the movies! The pair run off.

Tofno! Seflora Teresa asks Cleo to follow them. Cleo embarks on her mission. She hurries without losing T and Beto from sight, their two little mischievous figures already half a block away. They ring doorbells and run aw Cleo shortens the distance with each step, getting closer but not too close. And so, she follows them. When they reach Insurgentes the boys run off, and turn, disappearing at the corner. Cleo hurries and turns the co to - EXT. —- INSURGENTES AVENUE - LAS AMERICAS CINEMA —- DUSK Cleo reaches the bustling avenue, brimming with its early Friday night energy. People walk in all directions and th street lights, the cars, the shop windows and the ads are lighting up.  81.

She sees people crossing to the other side of Insurgentes where the marquee announces Melody, but she doesn’t see t boys. She worries and walks to the following corner, searching. She's almost made it to the newspaper stand in the next corner when she turns and looks to -

And there, amongst the crowd coming out of the theater an spilling onto the sidewalk, she sees Sefior Antonio. He l light and happy and dances a silly step to the great deli and laughter of the YOUNG WOMAN who holds his hand. And that’s when she also finally spots Beto, hiding on on side of the news stand, lost in the pages of Caballero me magazine. Beyond, Tofio is also holding a magazine, but he’s not lo at the naked women in its pages. He’s looking at the othe side of the street: people are coming out of the theater his dad is playing Fred Astaire to a Ginger Rogers that i not his mother. In his silly dance move, Sefior Antonio trips with an OLD COUPLE who is annoyed. Sefior Antonio and the young woman laugh and hurry off.
So rude...! Sefior Antonio stops, turns and to sprays bullets at the couple with his make believe machine gun, escaping with t young woman, Bonnie & Clyde, hand in hand. Wednesday, March 24th, 1971.

Cleo’s riding a bus full of people. EXT. — DIRT AVENUE - CIUDAD NEZAHUALCOYOTL - DAY Cleo climbs down the bus, her six-month belly is obvious the contrast with the Roma neighborhood is evident too -  82.

The dirt avenue is flanked by large electric towers and riddled with pot holes where stagnant water pools. The houses are made of cement brick, corrugated cardboard asbestos sheets. There’s lots of trash and plastic. Cleo shows a piece of paper to a PEDESTRIAN who points to street up the avenue. Cleo heads up the street.

Cleo walks on. Misery is palpable, there are children and stray dogs everywhere and a stream of raw sewage running the street. Different music booms out of each house. Three dogs block her way and bark. Cleo crouches, pretend to get a rock and the dogs run off. She reaches a house and double-checks the address on her paper. She comes to the door and knocks. Impertinent dogs answer her knocking next to the entrance Cleo knocks again as the door opens. It’s Ramén. INT/EXT — DATSUN - OCEANIA AVE - DAY Cleo rides alone in the back seat. In front, Ramén is in driver's seat, and his friend CANCHAS, is in the passenge seat, smoking pot. He gives the joint to Ramén, who takes drag and passes it to Cleo, who refuses.

text: About a hundred young men in uniformed t-shirts and tenni shoes are in resting position, supervised by three instructors with martial airs, pants and sweat-shirts. They pay attention to a man in sweat pants and a sleevele shirt who makes an exercise demonstration -  83.
The man does push-ups with his index finger only. A young man standing next to Cleo says with admiration -
It’s Zovek.
(in disbelief) No...! Zovek?
Look at ‘im...
Is that really professor Zovek?
He’s done over a hundred push ups by now!
What? Does he always come here?

No, not always, but sometimes he comes to train them. PROFESSOR ZOVEK counts to 150, pushes hard on his fingers in one swift move is on his feet, crossing his wrists ove his head. The young men applaud.

You too can be a Kombateka! Every human being holds great potential he must develop through physical conditioning and through mental and spiritual evolution. Zovek walks amongst them. PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) You too can develop your potential. But don’t expect any miracles, the only miracle lies in your own will. Zovek stops -  84.

PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) This is why mental development is the true motor of physical development. He stretches his arms, taking his audience in - PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) And next up... an act! A strip of bandage hangs from one of his hands, swaying i the dusty breeze - ON THE EDGE OF THE FIELD -— Cleo and the small audience call out in surprise -
Ooooooh! Zovek exclaims -

This is a routine that requires absolute physical condition! Only martial arts masters and a few great athletes can master it! Professor Zovek extends the bandage to a YOUTH in the fir row. PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) Yes... You... please bandage my eyes. The youth walks up shyly to Professor Zovek and takes the bandage, starts to bandage his eyes - PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) Make sure they’re totally covered. You’ve got plenty of bandage there. They youth has completely covered Professor Zovek’s eyes. PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) Thank you, you may return to your place. The youth walks back to his spot.  85. PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) And now...! Professor Zovek flexes his biceps and puts the fingers in both of his hands together in a diamond shape over his he He inhales deeply and - PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) (Exhaling) Huuuuuuuh! He is quiet. The young people look on, expectantly.

text: Cleo and the small audience look on in awe. Professor Zovek is standing, motionless, with his diamond over his head and slowly, very slowly starts to lift his foot. Time has stopped. The left foot lifts up, folding at the knee until the thi is at a 45 degree angle, and he remains motionless in tha position. The young people await in confusion for something to happ

head_text.subj: AT THE EDGE OF THE FIELD -

text: Cleo and the small audience are also waiting, a boy crouc down. Professor Zovek continues on, motionless - PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) Are you disappointed? Were you expecting me to lift a jet or an elephant? The audience laughs. PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) You are witnessing an incredible feat! You don’t believe me? Try it. Professor Zovek talks but remains motionless - PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) Just close your eyes and lift up a foot. (MORE )

PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) You don’t have to lift your leg to a forty-five degree angle like me or put your arms up. Just close your eyes and lift a foot. IN THE ROWS -— The young men close their eyes and try lifting one foot. quickly lose their balance. The instructors also try it without succeeding.

text: Cleo and the small audience also tries it out, some child lasts a little longer but they all fail. Professor Zovek explains -— PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) True mental preparation is the path to physical realization.
